site.title: Collections as Data Explorer
site.description: This site is a 'Collections as Data' visualization environment for Temple University Libraries' digital repositories. While you can find the full, comprehensive collections hosted dynamically on Temple's ContentDM instance, this site focuses on remediating, analyzing, and visualizing a curated selection of those collections. By treating these curated collections as datasets, we can explore big-picture questions about the temporal spread, geographic reach, and sheer scale of our cultural heritage.

collections.title: Allied Posters of World War I
collections.description: A striking collection of over 200 Allied propaganda posters from World War I, featuring recruitment appeals, war bond campaigns, and morale-boosting imagery from the United States, Great Britain, France, and other Allied nations. Held by Temple University Libraries' Special Collections Research Center.

items.title: I Want You for U.S. Army
items.description: Iconic recruitment poster featuring Uncle Sam pointing directly at the viewer.

items.title: Remember Belgium
items.description: American propaganda poster urging enlistment by referencing the German invasion of Belgium.

items.title: Beat Back the Hun with Liberty Bonds
items.description: War bond poster depicting a menacing German soldier to encourage investment in Liberty Bonds.

collections.archival_note: These posters represent the visual rhetoric of wartime mobilization, spanning 1914-1918. Originally produced as mass-printed broadsides, they range from lithographed recruitment appeals to government-issued bond campaigns. The collection is part of the Special Collections Research Center holdings and has been fully digitized via IIIF.

collections.title: John W. Mosley Photographs
collections.description: Over 30,000 photographs by John W. Mosley documenting African American social life, community events, and cultural activities in Philadelphia from the 1930s through the 1960s. Mosley was a staff photographer for the Philadelphia Tribune, the nation's oldest continuously published African American newspaper.

items.title: Cotillion Ball at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel
items.description: Elegantly dressed attendees at a cotillion ball at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel in Philadelphia.

items.title: Easter Promenade on South Street
items.description: African Americans dressed in Easter finery promenading along South Street in Philadelphia.

items.title: Musicians at a Jazz Club
items.description: Musicians performing at a Philadelphia jazz club, capturing the vibrant music scene.

collections.archival_note: Mosley's archive offers an unparalleled visual record of mid-century Black Philadelphia, capturing everything from cotillions and church gatherings to political rallies and nightclub performances. The collection is held by the Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection at Temple University.

collections.title: Philadelphia Dance Collection
collections.description: Photographs documenting Philadelphia's rich dance heritage, featuring the Pennsylvania Ballet and the Philadelphia Dance Company (Philadanco). The collection captures rehearsals, performances, and the creative process behind two of the city's most important dance institutions.

items.title: Sleeping Beauty
items.description: Pennsylvania Ballet dancers performing Sleeping Beauty, one of the company's early productions.

items.title: Rodeo
items.description: Pennsylvania Ballet company members in Agnes de Mille's Rodeo, performed at the Merriam Theatre.

items.title: David St. Charles - Lead Male Dancer
items.description: David St. Charles, Philadanco's lead male dancer, photographed at the company's West Philadelphia location.

collections.archival_note: This collection draws from Temple University's performing arts holdings, preserving the visual legacy of Philadelphia's professional dance scene from the mid-20th century forward. Both companies have deep ties to the city's cultural identity.

collections.title: Frank G. Zahn Railroad Photograph Collection
collections.description: Over 1,000 photographs from the Frank G. Zahn Railroad Photograph Collection documenting Pennsylvania railroads from the 1930s through the 1990s. Zahn (1925-2008) was a lifelong railroad enthusiast whose photographs chronicle the transition from steam to diesel and electric power across the Pennsylvania Railroad, Reading Railroad, and their successors.

items.title: Pennsylvania Railroad Locomotive
items.description: A Pennsylvania Railroad steam locomotive at a station, showcasing the engineering of the steam era.

items.title: Reading Railroad Freight Train
items.description: A Reading Railroad freight train moving through the Pennsylvania countryside.

items.title: 30th Street Station
items.description: Philadelphia's 30th Street Station, a major hub of the Pennsylvania Railroad system.

collections.archival_note: Zahn's photographs are a key primary source for railroad historians, capturing not just locomotives but also stations, yards, bridges, and the industrial landscape of Pennsylvania's rail network. The collection is held by the Special Collections Research Center at Temple University Libraries. On this site, all 1,000 photographs have been analyzed using OpenAI's CLIP vision model to generate visual categories.

collections.title: City Parks Association Photographs
collections.description: Over 200 photographs from the City Parks Association of Philadelphia documenting the city's parks, playgrounds, and recreational spaces from the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Association advocated for urban green spaces as essential to public health and civic life.

items.title: Fairmount Park Scenery
items.description: A scenic view of Fairmount Park, Philadelphia's largest public green space.

items.title: Children at a City Playground
items.description: Children playing at a city playground, part of the movement to create recreational spaces in urban areas.

items.title: Park Fountain and Visitors
items.description: Visitors enjoying a park fountain on a warm day in early 20th-century Philadelphia.

collections.archival_note: The City Parks Association was founded in 1888 to promote the creation and maintenance of parks and playgrounds in Philadelphia. These photographs document their advocacy work, capturing both the idyllic spaces they championed and the crowded neighborhoods that needed them. The collection is held by Temple University Libraries.

collections.title: NAACP, Philadelphia Branch Photographs
collections.description: Photographs from the Philadelphia branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), documenting civil rights activities, community organizing, legal advocacy, and public demonstrations in Philadelphia from the mid-20th century.

items.title: NAACP Annual Banquet
items.description: Attendees at the Philadelphia NAACP's annual banquet, a major community event bringing together civic leaders.

items.title: Civil Rights March in Philadelphia
items.description: Participants in a civil rights march through Philadelphia, organized by the local NAACP branch.

items.title: Community Meeting
items.description: A community meeting organized by the Philadelphia NAACP to discuss local civil rights issues.

collections.archival_note: The Philadelphia NAACP branch, one of the oldest and most active in the nation, played a central role in desegregation campaigns, voter registration drives, and community empowerment throughout the 20th century. These photographs are held by the Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection at Temple University.

collections.title: Temple Sheet Music Collections
collections.description: A diverse collection of American sheet music spanning the 19th and early 20th centuries, featuring popular songs, patriotic music, ragtime, and parlor songs. The illustrated covers are themselves significant artifacts of American visual culture and commercial art.

items.title: Oh! Native scenes
items.description: Farm buildings and a spire in the woods, sheep and man-made waterways.

items.title: Where are now the hopes I cherished
items.description: A woman embracing a man in Roman dress, while the man looks away; colonnades and a volcano in the background.

items.title: I'll meet thee in the lane
items.description: Woman stands next to fence on road through the woods, a church and field in the background.

collections.archival_note: Sheet music was a primary medium for popular music distribution before the phonograph era. The illustrated covers reflect prevailing tastes, social attitudes, and printing technologies of their time. This collection is drawn from Temple University Libraries' Special Collections Research Center.

collections.title: Paul Robeson Collection
collections.description: Materials documenting the life and career of Paul Robeson (1898-1976), the renowned singer, actor, athlete, and civil rights activist. The collection includes photographs, correspondence, and ephemera spanning his career from All-American football player at Rutgers to internationally celebrated performer and political figure.

items.title: Paul Robeson in Othello
items.description: Paul Robeson in his acclaimed role as Othello, one of the most celebrated performances in American theater history.

items.title: Concert Program
items.description: Program from a Paul Robeson concert, showcasing his celebrated bass-baritone voice.

items.title: Robeson at a Rally
items.description: Paul Robeson speaking at a rally, reflecting his lifelong commitment to social justice and civil rights.

collections.archival_note: Robeson's legacy intersects with nearly every major social movement of the 20th century. His papers at Temple reflect both his artistic achievements and his political activism, including his advocacy for labor rights, anti-colonialism, and civil rights. The collection is part of the Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection.

collections.title: Blockson Afro-American Collection Photographs
collections.description: Photographs from the Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection, one of the nation's leading research facilities for the study of the history and culture of people of African descent. The collection encompasses over 500,000 items spanning five centuries of the African diaspora.

items.title: Portrait of Frederick Douglass
items.description: A portrait from the Blockson Collection documenting prominent African American figures.

items.title: African American Military Service
items.description: Photograph documenting African American military service, part of the Blockson Collection's records.

items.title: Community Gathering
items.description: A community gathering captured in the Blockson Collection, documenting the richness of African American social life.

collections.archival_note: Assembled over decades by historian and bibliophile Charles L. Blockson, this collection was donated to Temple University in 1984. It is one of the largest privately assembled collections of African American artifacts in the United States, housed in Sullivan Hall on Temple's Main Campus.

collections.title: Temple History in Photographs
collections.description: Over 1,500 photographs documenting the history of Temple University from its founding by Russell Conwell in 1884 to the present day. The collection includes images of campus buildings, academic ceremonies, student life, athletics, and the university's evolving relationship with its North Philadelphia neighborhood.

items.title: Dean Laura H. Carnell
items.description: Dr. Laura Carnell in academic gown. Dr. Carnell was Associate President of Temple University 1925-1929.

items.title: Groundbreaking for Samuel Paley Library
items.description: The Hon. Charles Klein and chairman of the Board of Trustees at the groundbreaking ceremony.

items.title: Groundbreaking for Samuel Paley Library
items.description: Dr. Gladfelter turns the first shovel full of earth for the groundbreaking.

collections.archival_note: Temple University began as a night school for working people in the basement of Grace Baptist Church. These photographs trace its growth into a major public research university, documenting over 140 years of institutional and neighborhood history. The collection is maintained by Temple University Libraries' Special Collections Research Center.
